This video should be pulled by the NY Times for conflating opinion and science regarding a sensitive issue where the public needs all the facts it can get. This video drives forward the idea that lockdowns are a magic bullet solution and that the US's high number of covid deaths are mainly the result of the US not locking down.  Here is a well-cited peer reviewed journal article by Allen (2021), which uses far more rigor and faces far more accountability than, somewhat understandably, we get from this video journalist opinion piece, saying the exact opposite: "An examination of over 100 Covid-19 studies reveals that many relied on false assumptions that over-estimated the benefits and under-estimated the costs of lockdown. The most recent research has shown that lockdowns have had, at best, a marginal effect on the number of Covid-19 deaths. Generally speaking, the ineffectiveness stemmed from individual changes in behavior: either non-compliance or behavior that mimicked lockdowns. The limited effectiveness of lockdowns explains why, after more than one year, the unconditional cumulative Covid-19 deaths per million is not negatively correlated with the stringency of lockdown across countries... It is possible that lockdown will go down as one of the greatest peacetime policy failures in modern history."  This opinion video wholly ignores the inconvenient truth that lockdowns have their own negative consequences that can outweigh the benefits.  Of course, we should hold Trump responsible for his mixed messaging and anti-science rhetoric/policies.  We should also acknowledge that the issue of lockdown efficacy is a complex one, and it's easy for someone like me who is well off and has a partner and has a job that can go online to say we should all lockdown and cast judgement on those who disagree.

Link to Allen (2021):
https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1080/13571516.2021.1976051
It just completely shows Trumps ineptitude

Could we as a country have handled it better, absolutely. There were many areas we failed that we shouldn't have and yes President Trump bears some of the blame. BUT At the same time, you cannot talk about COVID like it was the black plague, like we failed completely because it was this extremely deadly virus we just didn't bother to acknowledge, that is a completely disingenuous position to take. The real data we had, showed that many millions of people under a certain age that didn't have comorbidities, were not nearly as at risk as an overweight person in their mid 60's. Had this entire thing not become political, we could have done a better job at fighting the virus while preserving our economy and our personal rights. We are STILL feeling the effects with inflation and all of the shortages because of the lockdowns we put the country through. Those had a devastating effect on the country, on ALL Americans, regardless of age or immunity to the virus. It got political and as soon as that happened, no one was listening to anyone. The left wanted to lock everyone and everything down for an unspecified amount of time and completely take over the entire country with the force of government control, constitutional rights and freedoms be damned. The right decided the virus wasn't serious at all to an extent and refused to get vaccinated (which is their choice anyway), and developed a rebellious attitude toward the public effort of trying to fight the virus. Both sides in my view are too blame for making it a political issue when it didn't need to be. It could have been an amazing opportunity to unite together in good faith and fight the virus together. But it wasn't, and COVID is still being used as a political tool by the current administration to pass student loan forgiveness, an action the executive branch has no authority to take. Our country is in trouble, and I'm not even sure if we can reverse course on this.

There's another factor that this video does not address, and that's the news media.  I'm not talking about how they covered the Coronavirus pandemic.  I'm talking about all the other times some new disease made any kind of appearance and the news media acted like the sky was falling when it wasn't.  My first question when I heard about the Coronavirus on the news was, "Is this ACTUALLY serious, or is this just another case of media panic?"  The news media, ALL OF IT, is always looking for something exciting to happen, whether it's a new disease or a big hurricane, or a politician being indicted or even just accused of wrongdoing.  Sometimes the hype is about something serious, other times the hype is just hype, and it's really hard to sort out how much we should be concerned about a given event when the media is trying to make everything into a mountain when a lot of it is just mole hills.

Yes, there are theories that the flu strain that caused the 1918 influenza pandemic was from Kansas that spread to soldiers bound for Europe. The theory I have read is that it originated in pigs with strains of pig, bird, and human influenza, which then spread to those handling manure (aka fertilizer). To be clear, this is one of many theories about the origins of the flu. Also, the reason that it is called the "Spanish flu" was that the pandemic was widely reported on in Spain, a neutral country that didn't have wartime journalism restrictions.

As a former scientist myself, I believe the answer to your initial question is that our medical institutions and government do NOT follow the evidence and conclusions of the latest scientific information. I have read some of the internal studies done at the NIH, for example, on the efficacy of iver mectin as a prophylactic against Covid infection. The small internal study, done on frontline Covid healthcare workers, suggests it is highly effective. This is also suggested by the central African Covid numbers. However, our health officials and politicians took a strong stance against this drug, and now are unwilling to publically back down and admit they were wrong. The recent Bangladeshi mask study is another case in point. I would happily wear a mask if that mask is effective. But the study shows that only certain types of masks are effective ‚Ä¶ so THOSE masks should be advocated, and it should be pointed out that other masks don‚Äôt work well. As it is, the people are deluded into using the wrong type of protective equipment. Germany, for example, issued all citizens an N95 mask (according to my sister, a former medical worker). Perhaps that explains the discrepancy in infection rates. The other possible explanation is a difference in testing and recording ‚Ä¶ but that is just my speculation, so take the suggestion with a dose of skepticism. As to Sweden ‚Ä¶ well, they are to story onto themselves.

This New York Times video documentary blames President Trump and other US leaders, including Democrats like Bill de Blasio, for high infections and deaths from COVID-19. This was published in September 2020, and it didn't age well. For example, they based their claim in part on Europe overall having better results, but things were quite bad in Italy, Spain, France, and the UK. There were times when Europe was worse than the US. Some of the European countries they presented as good examples eventually became serious pandemic hotspots. 



We know now that more Americans have died post-Trump than during the Trump era, even though Trump's vaccines weren't widely available until post-Trump. That's not to blame Biden. The virus doesn't care who your president, governor, and dominant political party are. The virus will do what it does regardless. Nevertheless, the NYT documentary makes some reasonable points and is interesting in showing what can happen when you try to tell history in real-time.

I think it was Chicago and Washington State.  I know because we left from Washington. The arguments over when everything happened, when everyone was aware, when people died or got sick, is absolutely ridiculous and beyond frustrating for someone who lived through it.

Deadly Germ Research Is Shut Down at Army Lab Over Safety Concerns  
Problems with disposal of dangerous materials led the government to suspend research at the military‚Äôs leading biodefense center.   

Safety concerns at a prominent military germ lab have led the government to shut down research involving dangerous microbes like the Ebola virus.
‚ÄúResearch is currently on hold,‚Äù the United States Army Medical Research Institute of Infectious Diseases, in Fort Detrick, Md., said in a statement on Friday. The shutdown is likely to last months, Caree Vander Linden, a spokeswoman, said in an interview.
The statement said the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention decided to issue a ‚Äúcease and desist order‚Äù last month to halt the research at Fort Detrick because the center did not have ‚Äúsufficient systems in place to decontaminate wastewater‚Äù from its highest-security labs.   

But there has been no threat to public health, no injuries to employees and no leaks of dangerous material outside the laboratory, Ms. Vander Linden said.  

In the statement, the C.D.C. cited ‚Äúnational security reasons‚Äù as the rationale for not releasing information about its decision.  

The institute is a biodefense center that studies germs and toxins that could be used to threaten the military or public health, and also investigates disease outbreaks. FORT DETRICK LAB SHUT DOWN :  

FORT DETRICK LAB SHUT DOWN AFTER FAILED SAFETY INSPECTION; ALL RESEARCH HALTED INDEFINITELY  


Aug 2, 2019 Updated Aug 3, 2019   

All research at a Fort Detrick laboratory that handles high-level disease-causing material, such as Ebola, is on hold indefinitely after the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention found the organization failed to meet biosafety standards.
No infectious pathogens, or disease-causing material, have been found outside authorized areas at the U.S. Army Medical Research Institute of Infectious Diseases.
The CDC inspected the military research institute in June and inspectors found several areas of concern in standard operating procedures, which are in place to protect workers in biosafety level 3 and 4 laboratories, spokeswoman Caree Vander Linden confirmed in an email Friday.

The CDC sent a cease and desist order in July.
After USAMRIID received the order from the CDC, its registration with the Federal Select Agent Program, which oversees disease-causing material use and possession, was suspended. That suspension effectively halted all biological select agents and toxin research at USAMRIID, Vander Linden said in her email.
The Federal Select Agent Program does not comment on whether a program such as USAMRIID is registered and cannot comment on action taken to enforce regulations, Kathryn Harben, a spokeswoman for the CDC, wrote in an email.
‚ÄúAs situations warrant, [Federal Select Agent Program] will take whatever appropriate action is necessary to resolve any departures from regulatory compliance in order to help ensure the safety and security of work with select agents and toxins,‚Äù Harben said in the email.
The suspension was due to multiple causes, including failure to follow local procedures and a lack of periodic recertification training for workers in the biocontainment laboratories, according to Vander Linden. The wastewater decontamination system also failed to meet standards set by the Federal Select 
Agent Program, Vander Linden said in a follow-up email.
‚ÄúTo maximize the safety of our employees, there are multiple layers of protective equipment and validated processes,‚Äù she said.        .........................

Hindsight is always 20/20.  

China was dealing with a brand new virus that no one at the time knew  
1. transmit via aerosol droplets 
2. has extra long incubation period  of 7-14 days (instead of typical 3-5 days)  
3.  start to transmitting disease even when the patient doesn't have any symptom.     

And it all happened during the time of Chinese New Year in the city which has been a transportation hub for over 1000 years in central China plain, in which it is not atypical to have 100 million people travel through that city within the 2 weeks period during that time (and no, 100 million is not an exaggeration)

Given the circumstances,  it is almost understandable that the WuHan local government was reluctant to do anything to disrupt 100 million people's lives.    You see this kind dynamics play out through out the world, from Milan to New York.  

The differences is that China's central government step in very quickly and essentially overruled any local government's concern,  lock down the city,  coordinated medical resources, and submit the virus DNA to WHO in record time.

An example of how journalism employs poor methodology.  Numerous omissions and misinterpretations:
1.) First reported case in the U.S. does not mean actual first case in the U.S., especially given the asymptomatic nature of Sars-CoV-2.
2.) Johnny's unstated implication is that across-the-board external AND internal travel bans should have been put in place either as early as late December or as late as mid-January.  As in other countries in the Americas,  Sars-CoV-2 was also imported from Europe.
3.) The difficulty of developing a test and testing is due to the limitations on the CDC's limitations on translating scientific knowledge of this (7th) new coronavirus into a reliable test to use on symptomatic and asymptomatic persons.
4.) Unlike other diseases, the combination of imperceptibility (high proportion of asymptomatic infected persons) and high contagiousness makes detection, containment, and eradication very difficult, and renders previous playbooks less helpful.
5.) The states in American federalism did lockdown to varying degrees and time periods and are still lockeddown and shutdown to varying degrees, but doing can't be done to extent done in their often smaller, mostly unitary Asian and European counterparts.
6.) Early on Covid-19 medical treatment was on a learning curve, for example, many patients were put on ventilators when they shouldn't have and died, but treatment and therapeutics have improved much.
7.) The medical and health advice communicated early on is still the medical advice communicated today.
8.) Like very cold winters, very hot summers push people indoors with other people, increasing contagion.
9.) Polonged shutdowns and lockdowns have negative health/medical consequences, as well as economic effects, which in turn have negative medical/health consequences.
10.) No mention of demographic and medical pre-condition commorbidities  that increase the likelihood of Covid-19 related death.
11.) Finally, no mention of expanding hospitalization capacities in every state that were not overwhelmed as predicted, no mention of improvements in therapeutics and treatments, no mention of timely expansions of medical supplies, no mention of health insurance coverage adjustments, no mention on impending vaccines.
But there were at least 45 distinct audio, visual, or name references made to President Trump, giving the mistaken impression that the United States is not only a unitary nation but a totalitarian nation completely controlled by one person.  That type of journalism does a disservice to the public.

The graph featured in the video measures new daily cases per total cases, with weekly deaths on the y axis and total deaths on the x axis, with a logarithmic scale. Be careful not to read the graph wrong, as it does not show time on either axis. The video creator shows time by animating the graph.

This form of graph can be much more useful than the classic "daily cases vs time" or "total cases vs time."

want to show us the data that masks prevent transmission?  All i hear is repetition in media and gov't officials, wear a mask.   Yet when i go looking for data i find something completely different.

@DoYouThinkForUrselF it is known to be spread in part through aerosol, fomites, and droplets. Fomites can be best described as any object upon which viruses are Laden. For instance, if you wipe your nose and touch your clothes, your clothes would be a fomite in this setting. Aerosols and droplets are really the same thing but the key distinction is size. Virus is present in open-air leave the body when they are attached to some object or cluster of water molecules in the form of aerosol or droplets. What you have to remember is that at the molecular and viral scale, air behaves far more like a gel or semi-solid material. Water and solid particles at the sizes that allow for viruses to spread through the air don't really face the same kind of restrictions to gravity due to their small size. Instead, other forces play a much bigger role. A good example of this can be seen when you look at something like the fairy fly, the smallest insect. It doesn't have wings in the traditional sense and can be more accurately described as swimming through air rather than flying.  Google it if you're interested.  This video can give you a pretty good primer to get you in the right mind space (https://youtu.be/f7KSfjv4Oq0). They're really out there. That said, these insects are relatively large by the standard we were talking about at between 1/2 millimeter and 1 mm.  For reference, the current debate over how to divide droplets which are larger and aerosols which are smaller range is between Drawing the Line somewhere at 5 micrometers to 20 micrometers. An aerosol would be the smaller of the two. One micrometer is a thousand times smaller than 1 mm. All this is kind of getting in the Reeds but it gives you an idea about the environment that droplets and aerosol are present in.  As a result, they don't really fall in the same sense of the word that we are used to. When you breathe out particles of droplets and aerosol, they linger in the air. The viruses in comparatively larger droplets fall faster to the ground and thus do not have as large of a range as they would have they been attached to aerosol particles. It's not that they are more affected by gravity but as I mentioned, they are much more subject to other forces at that size. Water naturally evaporates when in liquid form and droplets and aerosols are no different. Virus is present on water particles sufficiently small as to evaporate faster than the effects of gravity would cause them to fall into their size have a further spread because I mentioned, air behaves a lot more like a gel at that scale.  This is why they talked about aerosol spread being so much more dangerous. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC7293495/

A cloth face mask catches these water molecules preventing a great deal of virus particles being spread.  When your breath must pass through multiple layers of tightly woven fabric, it doesn't really stop small viruses but it does stop a lot of the particles in which they are present. Viruses rely on riding on those particles. Does it stop all of them, no. Does it stop free-floating viruses? Perhaps but not really given their size. Is stopping some spread better than taking no steps to mitigate spread?  Of course.

Single layer cloth masks are not really that effective but multiple layers greatly increase the chances that these particles will be caught up and the virus along with them. Here is a study looking at the effectiveness of single layer cloth mask vs hybrid cloth masks for blocking particles greater than and smaller than 300 nanometers. For reference, there are 1000 nanometers in a micrometer (source :https://pubs.acs.org/doi/10.1021/acsnano.0c03252)

Also, it should be stated that all might spread will be reduced by having your mouth and nose covered. You can't cough or sneeze into your hands and promote fomites spread when you have a mask on

You fail to mention that when President Trump announced a restriction on foreigners traveling from mainland China from Feb. 2, 2020, the World Health Organization (WHO) who was on the ground in China monitoring the situation, along with China and the Democrats criticized Trump and Pelosi encouraged people to go to Chinatown.  There was a lack of information from the World Health Organization in the early days on measures that are appropriate for this pandemic.  The WHO was more alarmist about the Swine flu pandemic than they were about covid in the early stages and since the swine flu petered out and was never as big as predicted, you cannot blame people for not being alarmist.  If the WHO was on the ground in China and they knew this virus was lethal, why were they criticizing the USA, Australia and New Zealand for banning flights from China.  No nation apart from South Korea and Taiwan were adequately prepared for this pandemic, they had learnt from their previous pandemic and already had systems in place and adequate masks and PPE to effectively deal with the pandemic.  Dr Fauci and the World Health Organization discouraged people from wearing masks, as there were not enough masks for medical personnel.  The issue was that masks came from China and they were not exporting, in fact Chinese business people were buying up PPE equipment in the West, including masks and sending them to China and Hong Kong.  Masks disappeared off the shelves in the first few weeks once it became apparent that the virus was spreading rapidly across the globe.  The advice given to the public about not buying and wearing masks was then adopted by all governments in Western Nations and only after the second wave were people encouraged to either buy or make their own masks, at which time masks were made available, since China had started manufacturing and exporting them again and some nations started making their own masks.  Sadly aged care facilities were not equipped with PPE and infected aged were discharged from hospital and returned to aged care facilities, where they infected other residents, resulting in increased number of deaths, particularly in NY.  So the USA and majority of nations were not well prepared for the pandemic.  It is not enough to have a guidebook, there needs to be sufficient PPE and every hospital should have protocols and regular training for all medical personnel on the protocol and on how to use PPE correctly.  Contact tracing also needs to be improved and quarantine of infected people needs to be properly managed.  This pandemic has been a costly lesson and not all states in the USA did poorly in managing the virus spread.  This is evident in the much lower number of deaths.  Yes Trump did not take it seriously initially, but neither did the WHO and don't forget that Trump was acting on health advice.  He may not always communicate well, but once he was made aware of the seriousness of the virus, he did act very quickly in providing ventilators, PPE and funding vaccine research.  If we are going to point the finger, then we also need to look at how individual states handled the crisis and why some did better than others.  It's the same in Australia, all the states handled it well, except for the Victorian government, who mishandled the hotel quarantine, which accounted for 95% of covid cases.

I generally agree with what's presented in the video, and it's great that Johnny looked into it. However, I want to point out that the idea that a few weeks of lockdown stops the virus and solves the problem (16:37 in the video) is a big exaggeration. I know this because in my country (Ukraine) it did not work. We had at least two months of a very strict lockdown in March and April, and May was also quite serious. And then more and more limitations were removed. As a result, in spring we had a very light pandemic situation, and the healthcare system made a lot of preparations during this time to ensure it can handle more patients. But now it's autumn and Ukraine is #8 in the world by the number of active COVID-19 cases with record-high numbers of deaths, hospitalizations, and new cases for our country (https://www.worldometers.info/coronavirus/country/ukraine/). So a few weeks of strict lockdown are good, but far from enough. A reasonable set of policies offering something in between the strict lockdown and normal life has to be introduced afterwards, or the terrible events would just be postponed rather than avoided.

Numbers that Matter. 

The R(0) which is the infectivity estimate, and lethality, F is what we want to pay attention. Oddly these are not totally independent. For example, imagine a virus that is so lethal that a human cannot transmit because they die too fast. So if a virus is not very lethal its transmission rate is also going to go up because there are simply far more undetected cases that make it far more difficult to control. 

March 17th R(0) US National rate for the coronavirus is 2+, and F= ~3.5%. The current statistics suggest that as of first week of Oct. 2, the Covid-19 infectivity rate, R(0), was 1.06, and a death rate of 3.3%. Johns Hopkins University calculated the current lethality is 2.8%. They used a 14 day lag. A 21 day is better.  Any R(0) above 1 is bad. I just want to say that a very similar thing has happened in the U.K - supremely prepared for a pandemic, but this preparedness was constrained by a decade of austerity and cutbacks. We also didn't learn from prior mistakes, have eye watering levels of incompetence within the government (the person in charge of our covid-19 track and trace system is a former CEO of a phone company, not an experienced epidemiologist), confused and inarticulate health communications, a leader who didn't take it seriously to begin with (according to Johnson the U.K was going to 'zig' whilst other nations 'zagged' to benefit financially from the virus) and would rather put in effort distracting the public from the crisis by manufacturing culture wars and pulling grand, unworkable schemes from thin air. But the worst thing, unlike Trump, is that the government have argued that it is our national duty as citizens to follow the regulations set - which change on a weekly basis, are often contradictory and literally depend on 'the common sense of the British people'  - and have themselves not followed them and have not been punished when government officials break them. 

There is a common theme running between the countries which have performed comparatively poorly across the globe - populist leadership, specifically populist male leadership. Russia, Brazil, the Philippines, India, U.K, USA have all done horrifically, and are run by so called strong men who are liberal with facts during 'normal' times and have intensified this tendency (certainly in the U.K) during a time where facts, the truth and statistical evidence are essential in combatting the pandemic. It is this development and their supporters and cheer leaders who are to blame for the worst excesses of this pandemic. If one positive arises from the hideous mess of 2020, I hope it is the precipitous decline of populism.

Allow me to quote my epidemiology text book
"Epidemiology studies tend to produce less reliable data that can be more difficult to interpret.¬† For instance, it is¬†extremely rare that an epidemiology study¬†alone can confirm that a particular chemical or viral exposure caused a health effect. ¬†Moreover, as noted by Stanford University professor Dr. John Ioannidis, the vast majority of published epidemiology studies are¬†later proven to be wrong.

Furthermore, with the exception of randomized-control trials that research potentially beneficial therapeutic pharmaceuticals, it is considered unethical to randomly allocate humans into exposed and unexposed groups. So epidemiologists can only observe, not control, the conditions under which people are exposed. Consequently, a vast, unknown number of other variables, referred to as¬†confounders, may cloud our understanding of the relationship between an exposure and observed health effects.¬†

Errors in measurements of exposure and disease also can occur, which can further skew findings. Potential confounding and measurement errors are especially problematic in studies that include a relatively small number of subjects (i.e., less than tens of thousands), report exposures near background levels and¬†report weaker relationships (e.g., increased risks less than 3 fold between groups).¬†Finally, not all epidemiology study designs produce equally strong evidence (see Figure, ‚ÄúEvidence Hierarchy of Epidemiological Study Design‚Äù).

The real timeline for this disease proper begins in Sept. 2019, not Dec  The real timeline about preparations includes the ideology imposed during the Obama years to suppress honest thinking about travel restrictions.
The timeline picks up in late Nov.-early Dec. 2019, when China-critical sources report how serious this new outbreak is. And our media and institutions do their best to downplay it.
The epidemic was covered up in this period not just by China but, soon, also by WHO (at China's behest) out of deference to its political leadership's conception of its diplomatic protocol. Also minimized by CDC, and by our major media - our collective NY Times, so to speak.
There was the nonsense about no aerosol transmission. That face masks are useless and counterproductive because our people are too dumb to use them right. Dr Fauci and many others said this. They later lied even when admitting their original lie, and said their only motivation for lying was the noble one that we didn't have enough masks. But their social put-down motivation was there in the public record, expressed openly for all to see like a classic Fredian slip.
And then the nonsense from these same institutions that our people shouldn't panic, the panic and panicky "misinformation" is more dangerous that the virus itself, it's an "epidemic of misinformation" (meaning by this, mostly, the relatively few people who were correcting WHO's and CDC's official false and misleading statements). And that it's like another flu, people our people stupidly fear and panic about and "other" things that are new and foreign and different. 
These were all ideologically motivated lines, all established as public dogma by your own cohort. The motivation consisted of the psychological and social as well as political-ideological needs of our progressive classes, which habitually look for a way to deploy this language to deplore our people in every new situation and position themselves as morally and intellectually superior.
It also fit in with the political-ideological attacks that soon followed, which called it "racist" and "xenophobic" to impose travel restrictions on China. Repeating here not just China's tactical word choices but a language for suppressing honesty that was developed and entrenched in our own media and institutions. China was using this ideological shaming language, which China itself despised (China really is racist and proud of it), only because it knew it was the invincible language of our progressive media for suppressing honest thinking and getting the West to do what China wanted. It eventually stopped working even for this purpose, but only when it was too late for us and Europe. The ideological language about travel restrictions being "racist" and "xenophobic" had been already imposed as a collective social dogma in CDC and WHO in the Obama years during the epidemics back then, something easy to do since it had been imposed among our media and academic classes, including medics, years earlier. This was the root cause of Dr Fauci's resistance to travel restrictions until it was too late, and the collective progressive class's use of it to deplore travel restrictions at the end of Jan. 2020. Which is what prevented them from being carried out consistently, and from getting extended in a timely way to other countries that were refusing to restrict travel with China, in Europe because they and their media were repeating after our media in deploring America's restrictions on China; something they perhaps inevitably did since they've made an entrenched practice of repeating after our media in deploring everything about Trump, true or false no matter just as it is no matter to our own dominant media. 
What became of the lies about how there's no evidence of aerosol transmission? Months later this language was changed by WHO and CDC, but only to "no perfect proof of it", still denying that the fact that it was real after the consequences of the lie had gone global. Only recently admitting what was obvious to honest observers from the start. 
What became of the lies on facemasks? They went through the same long, ambiguous process for correcting their lie on facemasks. Only changed it for a long time to "facemasks help only the other person not yourself." Finally now admitting that that's not true either. In the meantime, they convinced Trump to take up their line on this, then attacked him for it, then he dug in with his instinct of punching back at their attacks, and we ended up with the usual two camps of liars on both sides who take it for granted that they're on the side the truth because they're against the other one.
And what of the language for discouraging taking this seriously and responding on an adequate scale, by saying "don't panic", stop "overreacting", the panic and overreaction are more dangerous than the virus itself? Our media and institutions really did convince Trump on this one == that this is his job description as President, to prevent what the media will call "panic" and "overreaction". Which are more deplore word for our dumb people. What is put down as "panic" includes ever healthy psychological reaction, all the ones that are needed to orient people's minds toward dealing seriously and adequately with a pandemic, since a pandemic is a problem that mushrooms out of control at an exponential pace and any sufficient reaction will look initially like a wild panicky overreaction. To be sure, Trump had less of the malicious motivation against our people; his motivation was more the Kudlow one of not wanting a Wall St. panic. This is a perfectly normal and even justified motivation during normal financial crises. But was dead wrong in the present, pandemic-based crisis.And Trump dug himself in on this, too, like the facemasks, in his and the media's back and forth on it, when the media turned around and blamed him for saying and doing what the media had strictly instructed him that he must say and do.
There's also the CDC-FDA testing fiasco, which you try to blame on Trump rather than on their institutional attitudes of being in command. I like the enthusiasm of the presenter however my thoughts liken this report to period op-eds on how incredible the Maginot Line would be to the defence of France - it was a fantastic work of military engineering but neglected to consider the friendly neighbour Belgium as an attack vector! Yeah great that America as you state  "wrote the global playbook for pandemic response" but that only covered most of the pandemics to date at the time of publication. Just like Maginot factored in most of the previous European invasion activity of the prior millennia into designing a very expensive line that would have withstood all of the known major offensives!   

Sadly (in hindsight) America's playbook while scientifically sound (and if followed will likely be highly effective for the majority of future pandemics) has to make narrow assumptions (based on practicality) and will be fundamentally challenged. Despite being solidly based on volumes of prior research on the spread and typical modus operandi of the myriad of predecessor numerically high casualty lethal global pandemics and fatal coronaviruses Covid-19 does NOT follow the steps in that playbook. Almost all of those pandemics have a rapid onset of measurable conditions and feature notable degradation within a few days of contracting. Most of the expected pandemic symptoms are severe enough that there are few mysteries about those who will be spreading the virus. 

Covid-19 is highly infectious and shares many end-state lethality traits of prior pandemics but only in a minority of patients. Unlike the playbook assumptions, Covid-19 symptoms are highly varied, can be confused with other minor ailments in some and are barely discernable in many thus something like a simple infection zone border temperature "check" will be ineffective. Periodicity is another factor where Covid-19  operates on a very long multi week cycle that may only manifest maximum lethality in a few patients towards the end of the infection period. Spread by highly infectious asymptomatic individuals over several weeks of time is another feature of Covid-19 that would be nigh on impossible to factor into any playbook. Global contact tracing has proven to be effective to a point but given the long dwell factor is generally unsustainable. To counter this a playbook would have to factor in (staff-up and budget for) mechanisms to enable regular mass testing of populations of each state in the country - I can't see any country willing to fund that. 

As for the reported high proportion of deaths in the US. One has to consider contributing factors like long life expectancy, low general levels of fitness, social mobility, individual freedoms, questionable hygiene and so on. A totalitarian regime with no individual freedoms can mandate all manner of pandemic stifling population restrictions at the point of a gun (and can bury the negative statistics if things get out of hand). A third world country that has poor infrastructure, minimal medical support and poor reporting may never actually report anything like a realistic statistic. The US is certainly among the best at accurately tracking the number of Covid-19 attributable deaths so I would challenge that much of the remaining global death statistics are grossly under-reported.

Here's what an opinion looks like: This crisis and its impact on the economy is like the Stanford Marshmallow Experiment. We needed a president who could recognize that we needed to hold off on eating the marshmallow for a few minutes so that we could get two later, we needed a president who could recognize that the choice was between severe short term economic pain and severe protracted economic pain. We stayed home a solid 2.5 weeks, but when we ran out of food i went out to get some. There was nothing on the shelfs. Not only did i have to go to 5 stores, i could only get 3 days worth of food.  Each store was packed full of people to the limit of capacity and had an average of a hour long wait line to get in. Only about 5% of people i saw then had masks but they bathed in sanitizer when the went in and came out of the store. Most just had gloves on thats it.

After week 4 i had to go out daily to get only one days worth of food shopping to as many stores as i could. I ended up having to go to MicDonalds each morning for breakfast and sometimes lunch or dinner. We cut our meals down to 2 a day and sometimes 1 meal and one small snack. 

We had to spend much more money then normal on living costs during the shutdown because of extra travel and forced to buy higher priced items we normally would not buy and eating out daily. People in worse financial positions then us had an even harder time and were less able to remain at home at all. 

The lack of supply meeting demand and stores able to maintain enough shipments to remained stocked with even just the basics is why our area failed at the shutdown.

I must say that I am really annoyed by those who equates Covid-19 with the plague or calls it a new plague. The plague is a disease on its own, not some kind of phenomena (like a pandemic). The plague, and especially the Black death somewhere between 30 - 60% of the European population. It is estimated to have decreased the world population from ca. 475 million to ca. 375 million. That would be as if Covid-19 killed ca. 1,5 billion people (instead of ca. 1 million, as the time of writing). The plague wiped out entire communities, it lead to fundamental changes in how their economy worked, what kind of freedom people had and impacted generations to come. To compare Covid-19 with the plague is to compare a "mountain" in Denmark with a mountain in the Himalayas. 

Don't misunderstand me, both circumstances are awful. Nobody should have to die due to society's unwilling to take action or responsibility for its members. But just as we a responsibility to care for people, we also a responsibility to portray our history a fair and responsible way. 

I'm sure both NYT and Johnny is capable of a more precise and fair language than this word-baiting. I think Philip Alcabes has a lot of good points in his editorial in the American Scholar ("Coronavirus: This Is Not a Plague", April 6, 2020). https://theamericanscholar.org/coronavirus-this-is-not-a-plague/#.X3mlVGj7TSE 

(tl;dr: I'm complaining about the headline at 1:36).

BatRaTG-13 is a lab sample at Wuhan taking in 2013, and the wild virus has mutated.  Other than the furin sequence and mutation in the Italian strain, it is a 100% match to the lab sample, not the wild virus.
Trump approved the gain-of-function that Obama had stopped.  Were did the bas virus come from though?

I suspect a neutered for low transmissibility and used to study pathogenic code.  I suspect this as the virus appears to have inserts from Measles, Mumps, SARS, MERS, HIV-1, cobra neurotoxin/rabbis, and some potentially computationally derived sections.  For this to happen naturally is not plausible as SARS isn't in nature any more, and HIV-1 inserts couldn't naturally happen.  All the matches are to lab strains, not natural ones.

Here‚Äôs what happened: Comparing stats between countries in this way is a stupid thing to do. Do you know the percentage of tests done to record a confirmed case? The US has one of the highest in the world so more cases are going to be confirmed. In the UK we made mistakes with the death count because some deaths were assumed to be due to COVID19 but never tested and confirmed. Each country will vary wildly because of this and the true figures are extremely difficult or impossible to know. 

Secondly, lockdown in a globalised first world country like America or Germany etc doesn‚Äôt eradicate a virus. The only job of lockdown is to prevent the overwhelming of hospitals. You must let the virus run it‚Äôs course whilst working on more effective treatments (which are readily available) and a vaccine. Measures have been taken in more thorough disinfecting and masks (although the effectiveness on the latter isn‚Äôt clear) and that‚Äôs the best you can do. 

Lockdown also kills people in different ways. Cancer patients who don‚Äôt get screened and treated in time. Neo-natal deaths. Lower income families who lose income and cannot afford treatments for other ailments. The list goes on. Lockdown isn‚Äôt always worth it. 

And lastly, Why haven‚Äôt you done a piece on how the real party that bungled this is China? Hmm? Where are your brave reporters on this one? China didn‚Äôt alert the world, Taiwan tried to warn the WHO but they ignored them because they are under the influence of China. .

.

While I was in Korea when the coronavirus hit hard, information was instantly at the tips of your fingers. Not too long after, contract tracing apps were built and released to show the routes a confirmed patient had taken. At a hotspot of a recently confirmed case, your phone will constantly have emergency alerts updating about which areas have been sanitised, etc. Many other countries were not as well managed and well informed as Korea. Another country that managed best is Taiwan too. 

The issue of lockdown is also arguable because in Daegu (one of the first hardest hit city outside China) did not forcefully lock the city down. There was no legal prohibition against leaving the city or entering the city but people took it upon themselves to stay in by taking up the advice of the government. The streets were mostly empty. Cafes and shops were all closed or opened only a very limited time. While there were people asking to shut the city down, their government did not take the extreme measure yet it was manageable because people were willingly staying in and distancing themselves without being forced to.

15:52 "Level Of Shutdown"?? Sweden barely shut down at all; they didn't mandate masks in most circumstances and their social distancing requirements were more relaxed than those in many U.S. states, but their death rate was very similar to that of the USA, UK, Spain or France and it has since declined to almost zero. Most experts in Sweden agree that it is close to herd immunity. Meanwhile, the countries with the most draconian shutdowns like Spain are still hiding from this virus, hoping it will just go away and are re-imposing lockdows against a virus they thought they had defeated. Trying to limit exposure of the general population to a virus this contagious is a fool's errand; the population would have to hide indefinitely (or until a vaccine can be trusted) to keep  the spread contained while the deaths, bankruptcies and other tragedies from the resulting economic depression would continue to mount. In areas with cramped, poorly isolated multifamily housing, locking people in their homes can actually increase the transmission of a virus and the viral load to which those people are exposed. The aim from the start should have been to keep the viral load of each exposure low enough to prevent serious illness. In August, the CDC briefly conceded that airborne transmission of COVID-19 in tight, poorly ventilated spaces was a significant factor in its spread (explaining the much higher rates in areas dependent on mass transit), but it soon retracted that statement under pressure from the WHO. Eventually, I suspect that they will again face up to this reality. There should have been more focus, from both sides of the political spectrum, on indoor air quality and the means of improving it. It's a scandal that buses and subway cars are still operating with all the windows closed after 9 months of this. There should also have been an intensive effort, starting in January, to verify air purification systems for spaces that can't economically be vented to the outdoors. Shutdowns and the police-state measures needed to enforce them should have been the last resort, not the first.

Epidemiologists - not just Americans - made sure a modern epidemic-response 'playbook' was available to every country in the world by no later than 2017.  Other countries were - obviously - better prepared, because they took the recommendations in those guideline books seriously and *moved fast* from the second week of January. The best-performing countries weren't in Europe. They were in countries where politics and fantasies of cultural superiority and exceptionalism didn't slow or interfere with the messaging from public health experts. In Australia, which closed off all incoming arrivals except for returning nationals by early February, the vast majority of infections which had already arrived by then HAD NOT come with people coming from China, but already in people coming from Europe and America.  But as late as March 17th., Mr. Trump was saying the pandemic was just a hoax invented to bother him, personally and dithered about closing the country off. In fact, he never did it and that's the FIRST step in pandemic response. You isolate the country, then the area first infected, and the individuals who might spread the infection after arriving from elsewhere. Mr. Trump is not quite balanced in his views about this problem. Nor was President Bolsonaro.  The genome sequence shows, too, that the massive outbreak in the US was not due to any direct flight from China. It is a mutation that developed in Europe. It came to the US *from Europe*. The single greatest tragedy is that New York's governor didn't have the authority to shut out all incoming flights, with returning nationals quarantined for 2 weeks at point of entry. That is standard response. As you'll see if you look past Europe to Asia and Australasia.  The world doesn't consist of just America and Europe.  New Zealand is the world's best example.

This was an excellent look at the ridiculous response in the US. As someone who returned from South Korea to the US amid this pandemic, I cannot overstate how different the response has been. 

I would love to see more journalism and analysis like this, especially on the early days of the Covid-19 pandemic in China. I noticed that Nick Kristof mentioned how irresponsibility Chinese leadership acted early on. I‚Äôm glad he mentioned that and because the context is how the US messed up here, I understand why there was not more said about the situation, but as someone who traveled from Beijing to Seoul just before the crisis hit a fever pitch at the international level, I have been following the response closely. I don‚Äôt think everyone has had the same interest or motivation to look at the early days or follow them as closely as I did at the time. Given Nick Kristof‚Äôs knowledge of Chinese and Johnny Harris‚Äôs excellent visual storytelling, I can‚Äôt think of a pair of people better qualified to examine the timeline of who knew what and when in Wuhan‚Äôs government, Hubei‚Äôs government, in Beijing, and among doctors at the municipal, national, and international level. I have yet to see a visual timeline as good as this one that comprehensively explains what we know now about the early days. There have been excellent timelines put together by different institutions but I think a deeper dive, a more comprehensive dive, one that ideally links what happened in China, the US, and elsewhere would be an incredible resource for generations to come to better understand what went wrong and right globally and to have a better chance at fighting the next pandemic. 

I hope NYT or another capable source will make a timeline like this that looks critically at the decisions made everywhere. I remember many people comparing the Chinese response in the early days to Chernobyl and I think that seemed to be an apt comparison ‚Äî it may be interesting to analyze the degree to which that‚Äôs a fair analogue of what happened and to explore the ways in which a political system that firmly opposes dissent may also inhibit necessary transparency in the interest of stability over safety.

I'm not just saying that because I'm a Taiwanese American who currently live in Taiwan.  I'm saying it because Taiwan is the single country that dealt with this pandemic properly.  

By that I mean, despite being really close to China and has a very large percent of the population living and working inside China, Taiwan has kept the total number of COVID-19 cases to just 513 with 7 deaths with a population of over  23 million.  In fact, most of the cases were from people entering Taiwan through air travel, and were detected at the airport or in quarantine.  

And if you look at your lockdown map, you'd find that Taiwan isn't blue at all.  Taiwan prevented the pandemic from spreading without going into a lockdown, and Taiwan achieved this by forming a national team to make medical masks.  At first, back in January, regular civilians could only buy 2 masks per week.  Taiwan's heath officials communicated clearly the urgency of the situation and held daily briefings to instruct people how to wear the mask, and how to correctly stretch out the life of limited masks by keeping them dry.  By March we can order 9 masks online every 2 weeks.  Since everyone was wearing a medical mask when they are out in public, especially on public transportation and inside crowded buildings, there was no need for a lockdown.  The economy could keep on going as the mask effectively formed a herd immunity like defense for the public.

The health officials over here are all experienced medical professionals.  The vice-president at the time, Chen Chien-jen is a world leading epidemiologist.  The Taiwan CDC was well organized.  They put a mandatory 14 day quarantine in place for anyone who enters the country.  They did contact tracing and tracked down all the people that came into contacts with confirmed or suspected COVID patients.  If the world is to learn from this terrible pandemic, they definitely should learn from Taiwan.

I feel like too much of the blame for the rapid spread of the pandemic is placed on Trump. Yes, he did not take it seriously enough at first. However, it is the will of the people to take the virus seriously that impacts the spread of the virus. Additionally, going to get tested is only reliant on the will of the people. The government can't force you to get tested. It comes down to culture. American culture is very laissez-faire. In the video, Johnny compared the testing rates to South Korea. If I am betting on South Korea to obey the government more than Americans, I might as well put my entire life savings. Furthermore, The United States is not a true democracy. It is essentially a federation of 51 states that sacrifice some jurisdictions in order to protect classical liberal values and beliefs. The states do what they please in terms of most of their laws. We have seen it time and time again throughout history.  A prominent example being Alabama and Georgia outlawing abortion. The president cannot sign an executive order to mandate that everyone wear a mask. The United States definitely downplayed the virus at the beginning of the pandemic but I believe the main reasoning has to do with the will of the people to follow the governments recommendations.

I agree.  I had a bad feeling about this from the beginning.  There's a lot I love about America, but there's a lot that needs to be improved, too.  I've survived some nasty diseases during my life (Yersinia pestis and encephalopathic viral hemorrhagic fever, for instance) and I've been in real, actual quarantine (you know, the kind where the room is negative-air-pressure and they lock the door from the outside) so I took this pandemic deadly seriously -- even before our city locked down.  

I stayed inside till almost the end of May -- I literally didn't go ANYWHERE.  I lived on canned and dry food, and never went further than our back yard (and then only to take out this tiny dog).  I didn't even visit my friend who lives two blocks away.

But even in an important and benevolent "quarantine" like our city was attempting to do, I knew there'd be lots of people who just wouldn't follow it.  I think it's the one bad thing about our American love of Freedom -- too many people don't understand that if we'd only locked down hard in the beginning, we could've gotten past this and reopened sooner, and saved thousands of lives.

I still sometimes see people online who think Covid19 is no worse than the annual flu, just because it didn't hit their town very hard.ü§¶üèæ‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è
